target:
This case is about four non-profit corporations asserting that the City of Colorado Springs held its elections off-cycle in April of odd-numbered years and alleged that this contributed to unlawful racial discrimination and ultimately violated the Voting Rights Act.

On June 1, 2022, the plaintiffs--the nonprofits Citizens Project, Colorado Latinos Vote, League of Women Voters of the Pikes Peak Region, and Black/Latino Leadership Coalition-- represented by the Election Law Clinic at Harvard Law School, commenced this action in the United States District Court for the District of Colorado. The plaintiffs argued that the City of Colorado Springs’ timing choice of its elections remains in effect even though Colorado municipalities are now forbidden from adopting it in the first instance and that it is highly unusual among Colorado cities and towns. Additionally, the plaintiffs argued that the Voting Rights Act applies to election timing and may require changes to when elections are held. The plaintiffs argued that the April off-year timing of the Colorado Springs’ municipal elections caused an enormous racial disparity in turnout. As relief, the plaintiffs requested that the Court enter judgment to declare that the timing of the Colorado Springs’ April off-year municipal elections violated Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act, permanently enjoin Colorado Springs from holding future non-November municipal elections, and award plaintiffs’ attorneys’ fees and costs of suit.

On July 28, 2023, the defendants filed a motion for summary judgment and argued that the plaintiffs did not seek to change the City of Colorado Springs’ election timing through democratic means, no Black or Hispanic resident of the City of Colorado Springs joined the lawsuit, and the City’s Black mayor opposed plaintiffs’ suit. The defendants argued that different election timing falls outside any Section 2 right or remedy. The defendants argued that the plaintiffs lacked a private right of action under Section 2. For these reasons, the defendants argued that the Court should grant defendants’ motion for summary judgment.

On July 9, 2024, the Court issued an order dismissing plaintiff’s claim for lack of Article III standing and finding as moot defendant’s motion for summary judgment. The Court found that the Court lacked subject matter jurisdiction over the matter and dismissed it without prejudice. The Court reasoned that the four non-profit plaintiffs lacked standing because the injuries that they pled were insufficient to confer organizational standing. The Court argued that the plaintiffs have “manufactured their own standing.” The Court concluded that the plaintiffs lacked Article III standing because they have failed to demonstrate injury in fact. The case is now closed.
target_paragraph: This case is about four non-profit corporations asserting that the City of Colorado Springs held its elections off-cycle in April of odd-numbered years and alleged that this contributed to unlawful racial discrimination and ultimately violated the Voting Rights Act.

annotation.explanation: Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act
annotation.checklist_item: Statutory or Constitutional Basis for the Case

annotation.explanation: Plaintiffs: Individual, described as four non-profit corporations (Citizens Project, Colorado Latinos Vote, League of Women Voters of the Pikes Peak Region, and Black/Latino Leadership Coalition)
Plaintiff: Citizens Project (non-profit corporation)
Plaintiff: Colorado Latinos Vote (non-profit corporation)
Plaintiff: League of Women Voters of the Pikes Peak Region (non-profit corporation)
Plaintiff: Black/Latino Leadership Coalition (non-profit corporation)
Defendant: City of Colorado Springs
Core allegation: Colorado Springs holds municipal elections off-cycle in April of odd-numbered years, allegedly contributing to unlawful racial discrimination and violating the Voting Rights Act.

annotation.explanation: June 1, 2022
Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act (statutory cause of action)
Declaratory judgment that the April off-year municipal election timing violates Section 2 of the Voting Rights Act.
Permanent injunction prohibiting Colorado Springs from holding future non-November municipal elections.
Award of plaintiffs’ attorneys’ fees and costs of suit.
Law school clinic (Election Law Clinic at Harvard Law School)

Parties, counsel, filing date, and forum: Four nonprofit plaintiffs (Citizens Project, Colorado Latinos Vote, League of Women Voters of the Pikes Peak Region, Black/Latino Leadership Coalition), represented by the Election Law Clinic at Harvard Law School, filed suit on June 1, 2022, in the U.S. District Court for the District of Colorado.

Background context: The challenged election timing persists even though Colorado municipalities are now forbidden from newly adopting such timing and it is highly unusual among Colorado cities and towns.
Plaintiffs’ legal contention: The Voting Rights Act applies to election timing and may require timing changes.
Alleged harm/effect: The April off-year municipal election timing allegedly caused an enormous racial disparity in voter turnout.

Requested remedies: Declaration that April off-year election timing violates Section 2 of the VRA, a permanent injunction against future non-November municipal elections, and attorneys’ fees and costs.
Complaint filed commencing the action on June 1, 2022.

The Court reasoned that the four non-profit plaintiffs lacked standing because the injuries that they pled were insufficient to confer organizational standing. annotation.explanation: July 9, 2024: Court issued an order dismissing plaintiff’s claim for lack of Article III standing and finding as moot defendant’s motion for summary judgment; dismissed without prejudice.

Procedural outcome: On July 9, 2024, the Court dismissed the case without prejudice for lack of Article III standing (no injury in fact; insufficient organizational injuries; manufactured standing), found defendants’ summary-judgment motion moot, and closed the case for lack of subject matter jurisdiction.
Court order on July 9, 2024 dismissing for lack of Article III standing; dismissal without prejudice; defendants’ motion for summary judgment found moot.
